data.title: 2024 Olympics: Simone Biles takes gold in vault, Sha'Carri Richardson gets silver in 100-meter
data.meta_description: Follow live updates and the latest news on Day 8 of the 2024 Paris Olympics.
data.text:
Team USA added 18 medals on Day 8

The USA added five gold medals, six silver medals and seven bronze medals to its tally at the Paris Games today, bringing its total medal count to 61 — still top among competing nations and groups.

The five golds were in gymnastics, swimming, shot-put and skeet shooting; the six silvers were in track and field, skeet shooting, tennis and swimming; and the seven bronze were in gymnastics, track and field, tennis, rowing and swimming.

The U.S. has 14 gold, 24 silver and 23 bronze medals, which puts it in second place when only gold medals are considered.

China leads in gold medals, having excelled in diving and shooting, and France and Australia follow the U.S., tied at 12 each.

Thirty-one medals were handed out today, and the U.S. got more than half, adding a total of 18 to its arsenal.

Katie Ledecky reflects on 800-free history, looks ahead to L.A.

Katie Ledecky sat down with Mike Tirico to discuss her historic performance at the 2024 Paris Olympics, where she once again cemented herself in the history books.

Ledecky said she knew her last race of these Games, the 800-meter freestyle, would be a tough one. The gold she won today is her fourth in the event, the same event that turned the global spotlight on her at the 2012 London Games when she was 15.

She becomes the first woman in history to win four Olympic golds in a single event — her favorite of all the recent stats shared about her enduring dominance.

"I think that's the one that means the most to me, I think probably the hardest of all those," she said. "Obviously Michael Phelps is the only other swimmer that has ever done that so I think that just tells you how difficult that is."

Ledecky said her history with the event was also added pressure.

"I put more pressure on myself for that race to get the job done there," she said.

With 14 medals, more than any other female Olympian, Ledecky isn’t slowing down. She plans to compete in the 2028 L.A. Games.

Snoop Dogg tries new food with Martha Stewart while fine dining in Paris

Snoop Dogg and Martha Stewart enjoyed fine dining at a Michelin star restaurant, where the duo tried an assortment of food.

Stewart introduces Snoop Dogg to canapés, which he says he thought were "Jell-o brand pudding."

Later, Snoop Dogg said "hell no" when Stewart asked him to try escargot. She called him a "wimp' when he refused.

Reporting from Paris

Team USA gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik won another bronze medal today. He’s shot to fame over the past week, becoming known as “pommel horse guy” and going viral for his Rubik’s cube skills and eyeglasses.

NBC News’ Stephanie Gosk has more with the breakout star.

U.S. stars team up for mixed medley relay gold and set a world record

The American dream team of Ryan Murphy, Nic Fink, Gretchen Walsh and Torri Huske combined to deliver a gold medal for Team USA in the mixed 4x100-meter medley relay in world-record time.

It was the first gold for Fink and Walsh. Huske swam her fastest-ever time to help clinch her second Olympic gold and bring the race home for the team.

"They set me up really well, and I'm going to be honest I wasn't losing, I wasn't going to let them down, I didn't want to let Team USA down," Huske told NBC after the race. "They just got me so fired up."

Ledecky shares her golden Olympic moment with teammate

Reporting from Nanterre, France

After winning the 800-meter freestyle, all-time swimming great medalist Ledecky shared her golden moment with Paige Madden.

Ledecky had her bronze-winning teammate join her on the top step during the medal ceremony. She had her arm around Madden, a now two-time medalist, as the "Star-Spangled Banner" was played and flag raised.

Katie Ledecky wins 9th gold medal, most by American female Olympian in history

Katie Ledecky cannot be stopped.

Ledecky won her ninth gold and 14th overall medal tonight, taking the 800-meter freestyle and concluding her fourth Olympic Games in style.

She became the most decorated female Olympic swimmer of all time Thursday when she won silver as part of the U.S. 4x200 freestyle relay team for her 13th career medal.

But that wasn’t enough for Ledecky, who defended her three-time title in the 800 free.

Read the full story here.

Taylor Swift: Katie Ledecky, Sha'Carri Richardson and Simone Biles 'never go out of style'

Taylor Swift narrated a new hype video for three American Olympic icons who "never go out of style."

"Never be afraid to show them who you are," Swift said in the video about Katie Ledecky, Sha'Carri Richardson and Simone Biles. "Especially when the whole world is watching, because there's no one way to be the best."

The video highlighted clips of the three top Olympians, who are having anything but a cruel summer raking in medals for Team USA.

"Katie, Sha'Carri and Simone: Three American stars," Swift said. "Three different visions of greatness."

100-meter bronze medalist Melissa Jefferson reveals her two track idols

and

Reporting from Paris

The rain didn't stop Melissa Jefferson from sprinting to an impressive bronze in the women's 100-meter final today, finishing just behind training partner Sha'Carri Richardson.

The 23-year-old American, making her Olympic debut, told reporters she felt "grateful, happy, blessed" after her win but remains focused on getting even better.

"I'm a baby in this sport," Jefferson said. "I have a lot of learning and growth to do, so I feel like those moments where I'm not in first place or not on the podium, I can take those moments and learn from them."

As for her role models, she pointed to American track legends Sanya Richards-Ross and Allyson Felix. Both have multiple gold medals.

"Just the way they carry themselves," Jefferson said. "For me personally, they molded and shaped the way."

Richardson takes silver in 100, Julien Alfred wins first ever gold for Saint Lucia

Reporting from Paris

Since qualifying for the Olympics in 2021 only to be barred from competing, Richardson had waited three years for the second chance that arrived today.

Separated, finally, from the Olympic gold medal she has long pursued by just 100 meters of a purple track this evening inside Stade de France, the American star coiled into the blocks amid falling rain and waited to reassert her title as the fastest woman in the world.

Yet right from the gun, Richardson was forced to play catch-up to Saint Lucia’s Julien Alfred, who left no doubt on her way to a gold medal in her Olympic debut in 10.72 seconds. It marks the first medal in any sport in the country’s Olympic history.

Richardson earned silver in 10.87 with Melissa Jefferson, one of her two training partners in the final, earning bronze for the U.S. in 10.92.

Read the full story here.

Simone Biles wins 10th Olympic medal with gold in vault, Jade Carey gets bronze

Simone Biles’ Olympic medal collection has officially reached the double digits.

The American star defeated Brazil’s Rebeca Andrade once again in the vault apparatus final on Saturday, winning her third gold medal of the Paris Olympics. It’s her 10th Olympic medal and seventh gold.

Andrade won silver and American Jade Carey took bronze, redeeming a disappointing vault final in Tokyo, where she tripped on the runway.

Read the full story here.

Athletes ring up wins with commemorative bell destined for Notre Dame

Dutch runner Femke Bol rang the bell today after an extraordinary performance in the 4x400-meter mixed relay.

She entered the final turn in fourth and hit her turbo boost button to pass the Belgian, British and American runners ahead of her to claim gold for the Netherlands.

The bell has served as a celebratory score keeper, a way to spike the ball, so to speak, for a variety of events at Stade de France during the games.

It was made to commemorate the games and will be installed at Notre Dame Cathedral as it's refurbished following the devastating fire of 2019. Engraved with the Paris 2024 emblem, it will be suspended in one of the cathedral’s bell towers to mark the games' legacy, planners hope, for generations to come.

The bell will resonate with the sound of 2024's special victories, like Bol's.

Joe Kovacs on third shot put silver: 'I'm really proud of where the sport's going'

and

Reporting from Paris

In Rio, Tokyo and now Paris, American Joe Kovacs has won the silver medal in men's shot put. This time he did it in the rain.

"That last-round throw was not a good technical throw, but it was a good emotional throw and I kind of found a way to make it happen," Kovacs told reporters after clinching the silver with his final attempt. "I'm gonna be probably more proud of that as a silver medal than all my other ones before because being in fourth place in the last round is not somewhere you want to be."

After the rain had started, the three competitors before Kovacs all fell on their last throws. Facing one final chance to make the podium, Kovacs was undaunted by the slippery field.

"If you got hurt in the Olympics swinging, you're gonna be happy about it," he said.

Kovacs expressed pride in how he and three-time gold medalist Ryan Crouser have elevated the sport. He remembered qualifying for Rio with a throw at the 19-meter mark. All three podium finishers in Paris threw over 22 meters.

"I'm really proud of where the sport's going... Of course Ryan's number one of all time, I'm number two," Kovacs said. "We're both pushing the sport to the best it's ever been, I'm proud of that."

Kovacs said he wasn't sure if this would be his last Olympics but that his wife, who is also his coach, would be key in making it to the next one.

"We got in all of our sessions during our kids' nap times," Kovacs said with a chuckle.

American Ryan Crouser wins third straight Olympic gold in shot put

Reporting from Paris

The best shot putter in track and field’s history spent this spring and summer experiencing something unusual: vulnerability.

Ryan Crouser spent tonight doing the utterly familiar — dominating his competition and making history in the process.

Despite battling elbow and pectoral injuries for much of 2024, the 31-year-old American stepped into the Stade de France ring tonight and was unchallenged from his very first throw en route to winning an unprecedented third consecutive Olympic gold medal at 75 feet, 1 ¾ inches.

It made him not only shot put’s farthest thrower of all time — Crouser owns the world and Olympic records — but also indisputably its most dominant.

Read the full story here.

Noah Lyles says he 'downplayed' the competition, but 'that won't happen again'

Noah Lyles had to play catch-up in his heat of the men's 100-meter today, but he advanced to the semifinal behind Great Britain's Louie Hinchliffe.

Lyles acknowledged he "didn't put enough emphasis on the acceleration" and that he underestimated the rest of the field.

"The moment’s pretty big. I’m pretty excited," he told NBC. "Of course, I'm not going to lie, I downplayed my competitors, but don’t worry, that won’t happen again."

Coming in second in the heat only added fuel to his fire.

"I think I'm more excited now that I didn't win that heat," he said. "I'm pretty scared for everybody else right now."

If Lyles makes it through tomorrows semifinal, he’ll run in the final at 3:50 p.m. ET.

Water polo team captain Maggie Steffens posts tribute to late sister-in-law, Lulu Conner

Maggie Steffens, captain of the U.S. women’s water polo team, posted a tribute to her sister-in-law who died two days before the start of the Paris Olympics.

Lulu Conner, the younger sister of Steffens’ husband Bobby Conner, died July 24 at the age of 26, Steffens said today.

“Live like Lu,” Steffens captioned the Instagram post, which included three photos. “I love you, always together. Time to fly.”

Read the full story here.

Swimming: Kate Douglass 'really heartbroken' for teammate Alex Walsh after DQ

American Alex Walsh was disqualified after swimming the women’s 200-meter individual medley, robbing her of a bronze medal in her only event of these Games.

Walsh initially finished third behind Canadian Summer McIntosh and fellow American Kate Douglass. But she was given a DQ for making an illegal turn as she switched from backstroke to breaststroke, and Australia’s Kaylee McKeown got the bronze.

“I was just really heartbroken for her,” Douglass said after the race. “I feel like she deserved to be on the podium with me.”

Nail-biting finish in men’s 100-meter butterfly final

Hungary’s Kristof Milak and Canada’s Joshua Liendo and Ilya Kharun authored a thrilling finish to the men’s 100 butterfly.

Tune in to prime-time coverage

Full prime-time coverage begins tonight on NBC and Peacock at 8 p.m. ET.

See the best photos from the first week of action

See all the photos here

Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce posts first comments since missing 100-meter semifinal

Jamaican track star Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce posted her first comments after missing her 100-meter semifinal in Paris today, praising her fans for being steadfast amid her disappointing evening.

"It is difficult for me to find the words to describe the depth of my disappointment," she said on Instagram. "I know that my supporters share and shoulder this disappointment with me."

Fraser-Pryce, who won 100-meter Olympic gold in 2008 and 2012, bronze in 2016 and silver in 2021, did not explain what kept her from the race, saying only that her community has rooted her in "immense gratitude."

"You all have been there for me," she added.

Tennis highlights: Australia defeats the U.S. in men's doubles in super tiebreak, take gold

The Australian team of Matt Ebden and John Peers won gold today after defeating the U.S. team of Rajeev Ram and Austin Krajicek in a super tiebreak.

Australia defeated the U.S., 6-7(6), 7-6(1), 10-8.

Boxing highlights: Imane Khelif wins fight, declares,’ I want to tell the entire world that I am a female’

+2

, and

Reporting from Villepinte, France

Algerian welterweight Imane Khelif, backed by a sizable cheering section, beat Hungarian Anna Luca Hamori in a unanimous decision today, clinching an Olympic medal.

Her victory came just hours after International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach defended its decision to allow her and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting to compete, saying concerns over their gender identity are “totally unacceptable.”

With Khelif’s latest win, she is guaranteed at least a bronze medal. She appeared to fight back tears and had an Algerian flag wrapping around her back as she spoke.

“I want to tell the entire world that I am a female, and I will remain a female,” she said.

Read the full story here.

Highlights from the third round of the Olympic men’s golf competition, where Xander Schauffele and Jon Rahm lead, with Scottie Scheffler and Co. chasing.

Men's 3x3 Basketball: Win and USA is in ... probably?

Reporting from Paris

The U.S. men's 3x3 basketball team enters the end of pool play in a most unusual position.

An American win against the Netherlands (4-2) tomorrow should advance the U.S. to elimination play, but that's not guaranteed. A U.S. loss would be damaging but not necessarily fatal.

The 2-4 Americans are tied with France and Poland for spots 5 through 7 of the pool, with the top six moving forward. The Americans, triumphant over France but losers to Poland, are tops in this trio — at this very moment — based on point-differential tiebreaker.

The Americans could win narrowly tomorrow but lose their point-differential edge — a highly unlikely scenario, but still possible. A loss to the Netherlands wouldn’t be helpful but if the Americans ended in a sixth-place tie with France, then the U.S. win over the hosts on Friday would be a ticket to the next round.

Get all that?

France plays eliminated China on Sunday while Poland takes on first-place Latvia, which has clinched No. 1 and might not have much incentive.

Flips, tricks, and crashes: Best moments from BMX in Paris

See all the greatest moments from the Olympic BMX freestyle and racing events, including stylish tricks and brutal wipeouts.

Men's basketball: End of the road for South Sudan, Serbia advances

South Sudan has concluded an incredible first-ever Olympic run with a heart-pounding closer to the men's basketball group play. Serbia won the game 94-85.

Even after Serbia took a 17-point lead in the fourth quarter, the South Sudanese didn't show signs of defeat and climbed back to keep the game close until the final second, the crowd rallying behind them. South Sudan's Carlik Jones played every minute of the game.

Meanwhile, Serbians Nikola Jokić and Bogdan Bogdanović put on an offensive clinic, combining for 52 points. Bogdanović had a game-high 30.

Although South Sudan's Olympic basketball journey has come to a close, its story remains incredible. The team made it this far without a single indoor basketball court in its entire country.

Serbia will play Australia in the quarterfinals Tuesday.

Men's basketball: To beat U.S., Canada will need to play 'perfect game,' Shai Gilgeous-Alexander says

Shai Gilgeous-Alexander visited Mike Tirico during the U.S.-Puerto Rico game, talking in the studio about a potential Canada-U.S. match-up.

Gilgeous-Alexander said with how strong the U.S. is looking, Canada would need to play a pretty much "perfect game."

Women's 3x3 basketball: USA beats China to move to semifinals

The U.S. women’s 3x3 basketball team is headed to the semifinals after beating China 21-13 today.

The Americans dominated the game, particularly from 2-point range. The U.S. hit four of six shots from deep, and China couldn’t keep up, only hitting one of nine from beyond the arc.

For good measure, USA also outscored China from 1-point range, and won the rebounding battle 21 to eight.

The States have won four straight games after starting pool play 0-3.

Men's basketball: South Sudan won't relent as Serbia leads by 5

The score is 72-67, and while Serbia has taken a slightly bigger lead by the end of the third quarter, South Sudan is not giving up.

South Sudan has been aggressive beyond the arc, with seven different players hitting a total of 10 triples. Carlik Jones has played every minute of the game. The team has also made 10 offensive rebounds, compared to Serbia's three.

Meanwhile, Atlanta Hawks guard Bogdan Bodanović scored 18 in the third quarter alone for Serbia.

America's 4x100 mixed relay team delivers gold and a world record

Reporting from Nanterre, France

The team of Ryan Murphy, Nic Fink, Gretchen Walsh and Torri Huske set a world record in delivering America gold in the 4x100 mixed medley.

Huske anchored the winning effort and held off hard-charging Yang Junxuan to hit the wall first.

The U.S. time of 3:37.43 bested the previous mark of 3:37.58 set by Great Britain at the Olympics three years ago.

Lorenzo Musetti serves Italy its first tennis medal in a century

Lorenzo Musetti defeated Canada's Felix Auger-Aliassime in three sets to earn Italy’s first medal — a bronze — in tennis since the 1924 Paris Olympics.

The last Italian tennis medal was a bronze for Umberto De Morpurgo in men's singles.

This is the second-ever Olympic medal for Italy in tennis, however, Sara Errani and Jasmine Paolini are playing in the women’s doubles gold medal match on Sunday and are guaranteed at least a silver medal.

Italy has never won a gold medal in tennis.

Basketball: Serbia leads South Sudan 47-44 at the half

In the final group-stage game of men's basketball, South Sudan is putting up a tough fight against Nikola Jokic-led Serbia. The winner will join the U.S. in the knockout rounds.

Three-time NBA MVP Jokic has put up 14 points and 8 rebounds in 15 minutes. Carlik Jones leads South Sudan with 10 points, including a last-minute shot in the paint to close out the first half.

Because of point differentials determining the two best third-place teams, Serbia only needs to keep the game within 23 points to advance, while South Sudan can move forward with a loss of 2 points or less.

Women's soccer: Germany advances to semifinals in penalties

Germany beat Canada 0(4)-0(2) in penalties today to advance to the semifinals in women’s soccer, where they will face USA in a rematch.

The U.S. and Germany squared off during group play, and the States dominated in a 4-1 win.

Both countries are looking for redemption at the Paris Games, and will have to go through one another to do so.

Germany exited last year’s World Cup in the group stage after failing to qualify for the Tokyo games.

The U.S. women have not won a major trophy in five years.

It's the Summer of McIntosh

Reporting from Nanterre, France

After Summer McIntosh was awarded her third gold medal and "O Canada" was played, Paris La Défense Arena wasn't through paying homage the Great White North.

As McIntosh took a victory lap, the PA system blasted Bryan Adam's "Summer of '69," surely to the delight of any GenX Canadians in the house.

Team USA's Jasmine Moore wins bronze in triple jump

Reporting from Stade de France

At a wet Stade de France, Jasmine Moore, from Grand Prairie, Texas, has finished third in the triple jump, bagging bronze.

Dominica's Thea Lafond takes the gold and Jamaica's Shanieka Rickets silver.

Swimming: Ledecky wins 800-meter freestyle for the 4th time

and

Reporting from Nanterre, France

Katie Ledecky wins the 800-meter freestyle swim.

Ledecky could not shake her Australian rival Ariarne Titmus who remained close the whole race and took silver with a national record at 8:12.29. American Paige Madden took bronze at 8:13.

Ledecky won her ninth gold and 14th overall medal, taking the 800-meter freestyle and concluding her fourth Olympic Games in style.

She became the most decorated female Olympic swimmer of all time Thursday when she won silver as part of the U.S. 4x200 freestyle relay team for her 13th career medal.

Richardson ran faster at trials

The time that won gold in the women's 100-meter today was 10.72.

Richardson took silver today, but in June she ran 10.71 in the Olympic trials race that earned her a spot on the team. It is the fastest time by any woman this year.

If she had matched that today, Richardson would have topped the podium.

Track: Flo Jo's 100-meter record remains untouched

Thirty-six years after Florence "Flo Jo" Griffith Joyner's broke the women's 100-meter world record in 1988, her 10.49 time remains elusive for today's sprinters.

Saint Lucia's Julien Alfred won gold in the 100 today with 10.72.

Track: Julien Alfred wins women’s 100-meter final, Sha'Carri Richardson second

Saint Lucia’s Julien Alfred has won gold in the women’s 100-meter final.

It’s Saint Lucia’s first medal ever at the Olympics. Alfred dominated the race, winning by 0.15 seconds.

USA’s Sha'Carri Richardson won the silver, while fellow American Melissa Jefferson took the bronze.

Richardson won gold in the 100-meter at the 2023 World Athletics Championships in Budapest last year. She also qualified to race in the event at the Tokyo games in 2021, but was ruled ineligible to compete after testing positive for cannabis.

Richardson and Jefferson were among three Americans in the race. Twanisha Terry finished fifth.

Swimming: American Alex Walsh loses bronze medal in 200 IM

Reporting from Nanterre, France

American Alex Walsh lost a bronze medal in the 200-meter individual medley after officials ruled she didn't properly make the turn from backstroke to breaststroke.

The bronze instead went to Australia's Kaylee McKeown.

Fencing: Ukraine wins first gold medal of Paris in women's team saber

Led by saber savant Olga Kharlan, Ukraine defeated South Korea 45-42 in a riveting women's team saber finale to win its first gold medal of the Paris Olympics.

After Jeon Eunhye brought the South Koreans to a 40-37 lead after the eighth relay, Kharlan earned eight touches in the final match-up to clinch the gold for Ukraine. Kharlan was the only fencer on the Ukrainian team to win any of her bouts.

Ukraine is now the first country to win women's team saber twice, having previously claimed gold when the event debuted in Beijing. Kharlan was also on that team.

On Monday, Kharlan won Ukraine's first medal of the Games by securing bronze in the women's individual saber event. She now holds the record for most Olympic medals by a Ukrainian, at six.

Summer McIntosh wins gold in 200 IM

Reporting from Nanterre, France

Summer McIntosh won the 200-meter individual medley in Olympic-record time, edging American silver medalist Kate Douglass McIntosh in a thrilling finish.

This win marks the third gold medal and fourth podium visit of these games for the Canadian prodigy.

Coming into Saturday, the 17-year-old had golds in the 200 fly and 400 IM and silver in the 400 free.

Watch Femke Bol's incredible final lap

The Netherlands took the mixed 4x400m relay largely thanks to its superstar Bol on the final lap.

How will athletes handle a wet track?

Reporting from Stade de France

With several events still to go tonight — including the women's 100-meter final — the rain is really coming down at the Stade de France and the track is covered in water. Much of the crowd is dry, thanks to the roof, but the athletes are not.

A record time but no medal for Sweden's Sarah Sjöström, yet

Reporting from Nanterre, France

Sarah Sjöström set an Olympic record in the 50-meter freestyle in a semifinal-heat.

Sjöström, who holds the world record in this event, covered the short course in 23.66 seconds. The 50 free final is set for Sunday at 6:30 p.m. local time.

Silver for Team USA in 4x400m mixed relay after stunning finish

Reporting from Stade de France

Team USA wins silver in the 4x400m mixed relay after getting pipped at the very last by the Netherlands.

Team USA's Kaylyn Brown looked well placed to take home the gold after starting the last lap in the lead. But the Netherland's Femke Bol staged a phenomenal comeback, reeling in Brown and passing her just before the line.

It was a real moment of high drama in the stadium, sending Dutch and neutrals wild. But it must have come as a disappointment for Brown and her teammates, Vernon Norwood, Shamier Little and Bryce Deadmon, after victory looked within their grasp. Great Britain got bronze.

Field: Ryan Crouser wins third straight gold medal in shot put

USA’s Ryan Crouser has won his third straight gold medal in the men’s shot put.

American Joe Kovacs took home silver, while Jamaica’s Rajindra Campbell won bronze.

Crouser won gold in both Rio and Tokyo, but had to overcome multiple injuries to claim another in Paris. He tore his pectoral muscle earlier this year after injuring the ulnar nerve in his throwing elbow.

Team USA tops the women's triple jump table... briefly

Jasmine Moore just took the lead in the women's triple jump final, posting a 14.67 in her second attempt. Well, she was in the lead until Dominica's Thea Lafond bettered it in the very next jump with a huge 15.02.

Still early days in this competition.

Kristof Milak on Hungary wins 100-meter butterfly

Reporting from Nanterre, France

Hungarian Kristof Milak won his first gold medal, taking the 100-meter butterfly, as two Canadians fought their way on to the podium.

Josh Liendo set a Canadian record with his silver medal-winning time of 49.99 while teammate Ilya Kharun took bronze.

Earlier in this meet, Milak won silver in the 200 version of this stroke.

At 16, Sha’Carri Richardson said there was 'no option' but to make Olympics

Reporting from Paris

Sha’Carri Richardson was just 16 when she knew running in the Olympics was going to happen — because "there’s no option" but to make it.

The teenager was in front of the TV watching the 2016 Rio Games, which featured gold-medal American greats like Brianna Rollins and Dalilah Muhammad, when Richardson made up her mind.

"Just sitting there and just like, 'If they can do it, I know I can do that,'" Richardson told NBC’s “The Podium,” recounting her thoughts in summer 2016. “I literally know if I’m doing this on this level, I’m going to get there. I’m literally like, there’s no option.”

Three years after a failed drug test cost her a shot at Tokyo, Richardson has made it, and is a medal contender in todays 100-meters.

Ledecky goes for four-peat

Reporting from Paris

If Katie Ledecky wins her fourth straight gold medal today in the women's 800-meter freestyle, she will be the first woman to ever achieve that feat.

She previously won the same event at London, Rio and Tokyo.

3x3 basketball: U.S. women overcome rocky start with four straight wins, will advance to play-in

After starting their Olympic run with three straight losses in the pool round, the U.S. women's 3x3 basketball team rebounded with four consecutive wins and will still have a chance to defend their gold medal from Tokyo.

With narrow wins over France and Canada Friday, followed by their 14-12 victory over China today, the U.S. will advance to the knockout rounds. Hailey Van Lith led the charge with a game-high of 6 points.

The U.S. will face China again at 4:05 p.m. ET to fight for a spot in the semifinals.

Women's triple jump final begins at Stade de France

It’s all kicking off in the Stade de France: javelins flying from one direction, shot puts from the other, and the fastest women in the world sprinting amongst it all.

Now it’s also time for the women’s triple jump final, which has just gotten underway. Jasmine Moore and Keturah Orji are competing for Team USA.

Women's soccer: Spain beats Colombia, 2(4)-2(2)

For a moment it looked like the reigning World Cup champions were going to face a massive upset during the quarterfinals. But ultimately, as the sun set over the Stade de Lyon, so did Colombia’s olympic dream.

Fifty-two minutes through the match, Colombia's Mayra Ramirez and Leicy Santos put the yellow, blue and red team up 2-0. Colombia seemed determined on maintaining their lead, swapping out their offense for better defense to guard their lead over the champions.

But Spain persevered, with Jenni Hermoso and Irene Paredes scoring a goal each to bring the score to a 2-2 draw after 120 minutes.

The match went into penalty shoot-outs with Colombia's Catalina Usme up first, attempting a goal that was saved by Spain's goalie Cata Coll. The Colombians didn't stand a chance after Liana Salazar missed her shot while the Spaniards scored all of their penalties successfully. Still, Colombia's Jorelyn Carabali gave the team hope, extending the shootout by scoring a third goal.

Nevertheless, the game ended after 4 successful goals from Spain, advancing them to the semifinals and sending Colombia packing, after a 2-2 overtime score with a 4-2 penalty shoot-out.

Track: Twanisha Terry books spot in 100-meter final

In the third 100-meter semfinal, USA’s Twanisha Terry just barely qualified for the final, making her way into next race by one one-hundredth of a second.

Three Americans will run in the final—Terry, Melissa Richardson and Sha'Carri Richardson.

Track: Sha'Carri Richardson advances to 100-meter finals

USA’s Sha'Carri Richardson finished second in the second women’s 100-meter semifinal on Saturday, good enough for her to advance to the finals in the event.

Running firmly in second place, Richardson seemed content not to turn on the burners near the end of the race. Julien Alfred of Saint Lucia won, running in 10.89 seconds. Both will race again in the final, as well USA’s Melissa Jefferson.

Track: Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce withdraws from 100-meter semifinal

Jamaica’s Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce did not run in the women’s 100-meter semifinal on Saturday, preventing her from competing for a medal.

The 37-year-old sprinter is one of the most decorated athletes in the sport. The reason for her late scratch is not known yet.

Read the full story

Track: Melissa Jefferson wins 100-meter semifinal

USA’s Melissa Jefferson won her 100-meter semifinal, advancing her to the finals.

Marie-Josée Ta Lou of Ivory Coast finished second, qualifying for the final as well.

Soccer highlights: Trinity Rodman's brilliant extra time goal

After struggling to break through Japan's defense for 105 minutes, Washington Spirit's Trinity Rodman expertly curled in a shot from 10 yards, securing a 1-0 lead that the team managed to hold onto to win the game.

Rodman, 22, is now the youngest player in USWNT history to score a goal in an Olympic knockout match.

The USWNT, aiming for their first gold medal since 2012, will face either Germany or Canada in Tuesday's semifinal.

Track: Allyson Felix's races to watch

In an interview with NBC News, 11-time Olympic medalist Allyson Felix previewed the sprinting field in Paris.

“I love the the USA-Jamaica rivalry," Felix said.

Reigning 100m world champion Sha’Carri Richardson and Jamaica’s Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, the reigning silver medalist, are both eyeing Olympic gold in that event.

She'll also have her eye on Kishane Thompson (Jamaica) and Noah Lyles (United States), who are medal contenders in the men’s 100m.

"I'm excited to go to the Olympics for the first time as a spectator," Felix said. "And to watch it through the eyes of my daughter as well, and to take it in."

Felix's signature race, which is also her favorite to watch, starts tomorrow as Gabby Thomas takes the first step in her journey to the women's 200m final on Tuesday.

That might be the last of Simone Biles' iconic namesake vault

While Biles said she is keeping the door open for an Olympic return in 2028, she said Saturday it would “definitely” be the last sighting of her iconic namesake vault, the Yurchenko double pike, or “Biles II.”

“I mean, I kind of nailed that one,” Biles said.

She scored a 15.700, clinching the seventh Olympic gold medal of her career.

Judo: Teddy Riner closes out Olympics run with historic fifth gold

Big Ted has done it again, lifting France to a comeback victory over Japan in the mixed team final. It was one for the books.

After Japan took the first two contests, heavyweight gold medalist Teddy Riner kept France alive with a thrilling ippon to win the third. Another win for Japan gave them a 3-1 lead before silver-medalist Joan-Benjamin Gaba and bronze-medalist Clarisse Agbegnenou managed back-to-back wins for France.

With the score tied at 3-3, everything hinged on the final pairing, which was determined by a randomizer on a big screen. When it landed on the heavyweight category, the home crowd erupted in excitement, knowing they could rely on 11-time world champion Riner to defend France's gold.

And he did it with another remarkable ippon, sending the packed stadium into a roar.

Japan’s judokas were left in tearful disappointment, though their silver medal adds to their total of eight judo medals at the Paris Games.

While judo may be considered a niche sport in the U.S., it draws fervent French crowds as one of the country's most popular sports. Much is thanks to Riner, who is widely regarded as one of the greatest judokas of all time.

With this win, Riner makes history as the first French athlete to win five gold medals at the Summer Olympics.

Tennis: Qinwen Zheng wins China's first singles gold medal

After dominating Croatia's Donna Vekić in straight sets, Qinwen Zheng made history for her country as China's first singles gold medalist in tennis. Overcome with emotion, Zheng collapsed onto the court immediately after her ground-stroke winner.

The 21-year-old entered her Olympic debut ranked no. 7 in the world, but had no problem in the semifinals defeating no. 1 Iga Świątek of Poland, who went on to win the bronze. Never having won a Grand Slam trophy, this is Zheng's biggest title in her career so far. She is also the youngest woman to win Olympic singles since Venus Williams in 2000.

Vekić became the first Croatian woman to win an Olympic tennis medal, while Świątek became the first Polish player to do so.

Basketball: USA wins laugher vs. Puerto Rico

USA finished an undefeated group stage with a dominant win vs. Puerto Rico on Saturday.

After back-to-back double-digit victories vs. Serbia and South Sudan, the U.S. beat Puerto Rico 104-83 in their last game before the knockout round.

Anthony Edwards was the star Saturday, scoring 26 points on 11-of-15 shooting, drawing oohs and ahhs from the crowd with a wide variety of offensive theatrics. Joel Embiid had 15 points, while Kevin Durant added 11. Contributions came from up and down the roster, similar to the States’ first two wins of the Olympics.

The U.S. will play its first knockout game on Tuesday.

Simone Biles keeps door open for L.A. 2028

Many assumed that Simone Biles, who is widely considered the greatest gymnast of all time, would retire after the Paris Games.

But after winning her 10th Olympic medal on Saturday, she said this may not be her last Olympic experience.

“Never say never,” Biles said. “The next Olympics is at home, so you just never know, but I am getting really old.”

The Games will be held in Los Angeles in 2028, the first domestic Summer Olympics since Atlanta 1996. If Biles competes in a fourth Olympics, she will be 31.

Judo: Crowd in a frenzy as Teddy Riner fights for gold

After fighting back from a 3-1 Japan lead, France has tied it up in the mixed team final. A wheel spin determined the heavyweight category for the final pairing in what seems like a fate-driven finale. The home crowd chants "Teddy" as their judo legend Teddy Riner holds their gold medal hopes in his hands.

The most dominant shot putter in history eyes a third straight Olympic gold medal — if his body holds up

Reporting from Paris

The best shot putter in track and field’s history spent this spring and summer experiencing something unusual: vulnerability.

It all started in March, when Ryan Crouser injured the ulnar nerve in his throwing elbow. The next month, while bench pressing, he tore a pectoral muscle.

Doctors didn’t clear him to resume throwing the 16-pound metal shot until almost June. By late July, in his final warmup before the Paris Olympics, the Oregon native was beaten for the first time in nearly a year.

When the 31-year-old American steps into the Stade de France ring in Saturday’s Olympic shot put final, it will be the ultimate test of a season he never would have predicted, one that has battered his body, if not his confidence.

Read the full story here

Here is your USA men’s basketball highlight of the day!

Anthony Edwards is cooking vs. Puerto Rico, and seemingly to emphasize just how much he’s hooping, he threw down this filthy windmill dunk in the fourth quarter that had the entire U.S. team on its feet.

Basketball: USA dominating through three quarters vs. Puerto Rico

USA has pushed its lead to 28, ahead of Puerto Rico 87-59 after three quarters.

The U.S. has four players in double figures in scoring, led by Anthony Edwards’s 19. LeBron James has 10 points, six rebounds and eight assists, and could probably get a triple double simply if he wants to.

Jose Alvarado has played admirably for Puerto Rico, scoring 18.

Puerto Rico entered the game already eliminated from advancing, while the States were guaranteed a spot in the knockout stage.

USWNT coach Hayes defends decision to avoid subs until 90 mins

After a hard-fought and at times ugly win over Japan, USWNT coach Emma Hayes responded to criticisms that her team looked tired by saying she believes they would have lost if she made too many substitutions.

“I don’t believe we’d have gone through if we made too many changes,” she said when NBC News asked if her team was fatigued and needed freshening up sooner. Hayes, a veteran British coach appointed in November after 12 successful years at WSL team Chelsea, did not make any changes until extra time.

“I haven’t had much time to work the whole squad; I’m still learning about everybody,” she said. “But the 11 that were there from the beginning did a fabulous job of sticking to” the game plan, “and the players that then came from the bench did their job."

“It’s was completely the right decision,” she added of the strategy not to switch-up the team sooner. “I’m paid to do this job. So all I’m interested in is what we do in-house.”

USWNT's Rodman said she 'kind of blacked out' after winning goal

Reporting from Paris

Scoring the winning goal in an Olympic soccer quarter final “is the best moment in my career,” the USWNT’s Trinity Rodman told reporters after her stunning strike was the difference in a 1-0 win against Japan.

“I kind of blacked out,” she said. “The last thing I remember was Crystal playing it over,” she said, referring to the assist by left full back Crystal Dunn, “and then I was just like, ‘Ahh! Ohh! Then once the game was over, that’s when I was like, oh, that’s what happened.”

Japan presented a difficult opponent, with USWNT struggling to break their organized defensive block.

“We tried all game long to get in the seams and get in between them but it wasn’t working,” Rodman said. Dunn “played it in behind, I think it a bobbled a bit, I did a little chop, and then bang — I couldn’t have asked for anything better and I’m very happy about it.”

Gymnastics: The luck of the Irish

Rhys McClenaghan just won Ireland their first Olympic gold medal in gymnastics, winning pommel horse gold with a 15.533.

It's been a long time coming for McClenaghan, who is a two-time world champion on the event and had a devastating error in Tokyo that left him off the podium.

His luck has changed in Paris. He can finally call himself an Olympic medalist, and a gold one too.

Gymnastics: Pommel horse podium

Rhys McClenaghan, Ireland, 15.533

Nariman Kurbanov, Kazakhstan, 15.433

Stephen Nedoroscik, United States, 15.300

Gymnastics: Stephen Nedoroscik wins pommel horse bronze

Nedoroscik will be the only U.S. male gymnast to medal individually in Paris, earning a bronze in his specialty, the pommel horse.

He scored a 15.300 with an even more intricate routine than the one that clinched Monday's historic team medal for the U.S. men.

Read the full story here

"Mr. Pommel Horse" lives up to his name

Anyone who said Stephen Nedoroscik couldn't handle the pressure will have to eat their words.

With a medal on the line, he scored a 15.300 and currently holds bronze medal position. Nedoroscik seems pleased, giving the camera a thumbs up.

Basketball: USA takes commanding lead over Puerto Rico

After a hot start from Puerto Rico in the first quarter, USA restored order in the second.

The U.S. outscored its opponent by 23 points in the second, taking a 64-45 lead into halftime.

Anthony Edwards has 12 points to lead the States. LeBron James has been the best player on the floor, though, racking up eight points, four rebounds and six assists.

After making four threes in the first, Puerto Rico missed all nine of their attempts from deep in the second. Meanwhile, every USA starter has scored at least six points in a very balanced effort.

Gymnastics: Big task ahead for Stephen Nedoroscik

Rhys McClenaghan of Ireland just posted a 15.533 on the pommel horse. That will be a very tough number for Nedoroscik to match, but he's up next.

Gymnastics: Stephen 'Pommel Horse Guy' Nedoroscik meditates before gold medal opportunity

Stephen Nedoroscik could be seen meditating on the sidelines and finally, removing his trademark glasses before clinching a historic bronze medal for the U.S. men's gymnastics team Monday.

As he prepares to contend for a gold in today's final, he seems to be in zen mode again.

Cycling: Remco Evenepoel wins men's road race for second gold

Belgian cyclist Remco Evenepoel has made history as the first male athlete to take gold in both the time trial and road race at the same Olympics. He won the road race by over a minute, outpacing France's Valentin Madouas and Christophe Laporte, who came in second and third.

Evenepoel's celebration was immediately iconic, lifting his arms in victory with the Eiffel Tower as a backdrop.

At only 24, Evenepoel adds these two gold medals to his impressive list of cycling feats, which includes five World Championship medals.

Gymnastics: Reigning pommel horse champ dethroned

Two-time Olympic pommel horse gold medalist Max Whitlock of Great Britain won't be quite satisfied with that routine.

He had a significant form break, splitting his legs slightly and earning a 15.200. Whitlock is currently in second place and won't defend his title, but could still medal.

Boxing: Algerian welterweight Imane Khelif wins again

Reporting from Villepinte, France

Algerian welterweight Imane Khelif beat Hungarian Anna Luca Hamori in a unanimous decision.

Khelif appeared to have a sizable cheering section chanting her name, “Imane, Imane, Imane!” and waving Algerian flags.

Khelif’s win follows her opening triumph against Angela Carini when the Italian pulled out seconds into the bout and later refused to shake the winner’s hand.

With Khelif's win today, she is guaranteed at least a bronze medal.

Basketball: Puerto Rico leads USA after one quarter

Puerto Rico is leading Team USA 30-25 after one quarter.

It’s an impressive display from Puerto Rico, which is shooting 4-of-7 from three. Jose Alvarado leads his team with nine points.

Joel Embiid was back in the starting lineup for the U.S. on Saturday, scoring two points in the opening frame. Jayson Tatum leads the States with six points.

This game is effectively meaningless for both sides—the U.S. is already advancing to the knockout stage, while Puerto Rico cannot advance even with a win.

Full time: USWNT beats Japan 1-0, advances to semi-finals

It was far from a convincing win, but they got there in the end. Trinity Rodman's extra-time goal gave the United States a 1-0 win over Japan, meaning they will face either Canada or Germany in the semi-final Tuesday.

Though the U.S. dominated possession, they lacked quality in the final third and were mostly unable to breakdown Japan's disciplined defensive structure. It took a moment of magic from Rodman to break the impasse, controlling the ball on the right-side of the penalty area, cutting back to beat her defender and curling a sweet shot into the opposite corner.

Questions will be asked whether fatigue is a factor; the team has rarely changed up its starting line-up this tournament. And the first substitution today only came after 90 minutes.

Biles, Andrade, Carey win vault medals

Simone Biles, United States, 15.300

Rebeca Andrade, Brazil, 14.966

Jade Carey, United States, 14.466

Simone Biles wins 10th Olympic medal on vault

Simone Biles defeated Brazil’s Rebeca Andrade once again in the vault apparatus final today, winning her third gold medal of the Paris Olympics. It’s her 10th Olympic medal and seventh gold.

Biles performed her iconic namesake vault, the Yurchenko double pike, or “Biles II" for the last time in Paris. Her second vault was a “Cheng,” which features a half-turn onto the table, followed by a 1.5 twist into the air.

Gymnastics: Jade Carey rises from the ashes

After a fluke tripping incident in Tokyo kept her out of the vault medals, Jade Carey will earn a podium finish in Paris.

She earned a 14.733 for her first vault, a Cheng, and a 14.200 for a double-twisting Yurchenko, giving her a 14.466 average.

First half of extra time is up in the soccer: 15 minutes to go

That goal by Trinity Rodman came right at the end of the first half of extra time. The question is how it will affect the USWNT in this last part of the game.

It has not been a convincing performance so far, with the U.S. unable to convert their dominance in possession into enough clear-cut chances, while allowing Japan too many attempts on goal.A win is a win, and would put the U.S. through to face either Canada or Germany in the semi-final. But if it comes, it will not have been a pretty one. They will want to play a lot better next time if they hope to progress any further.

Rebeca Andrade gives Biles a run for her money

Brazil's Rebeca Andrade did one of the best Cheng vaults the gymnastics world has ever seen, but it won't be enough to best Biles.

After Andrade's near-perfect vault, Biles could be seen smiling and shaking her head in disbelief at her competitor's prowess on the skill. Andrade earned a massive 15.100 for the Cheng and a 14.833 for an equally beautiful Amanar, averaging a 14.966, below Biles' 15.3.

Andrade opted not to debut the triple-twisting Yurchenko and instead did the 2.5 twist.

Archery: South Korea's Lim Si-Hyeon wins third gold of Paris

The archery masters reign supreme once again. After South Korea swept the women's, men's and mixed team archery finals, expectations were high for the individual finals as well. And they did not disappoint, beginning with the women's event.

In her first Olympics, 21-year-old Lim Si-Hyeon won the individual women's gold, securing her third gold medal of the Games after the women's team and mixed team events. Hitting eleven perfect 10s, she beat out fellow South Korean Nam Suh-Yeon. In the ranking round of this event, Lim had set a world record of 694 points out of 720.

France's Lisa Barbelin earned the bronze, defeating Jeon Hunyoung in a narrower match-up and becoming the first non-Korean archer to defeat a South Korean opponent in this Olympics.

Lim joins French swimmer Leon Marchand and Australian swimmer Mollie O'Callaghan in winning at least three gold medals so far at the Paris Games.

The men's individual event concludes tomorrow, with three South Koreans still in contention.

Soccer: Swanson out, Williams in

Extra time has now kicked off in the women's soccer quarter final and USWNT No. 9 Mallory Swanson has been replaced by No. 8 Lynn Williams, the team's first substitution.

Simone Biles nails hardest vault in women's gymnastics

Biles performed her iconic namesake vault, the Yurchenko double pike, or “Biles II” for the last time in Paris. It's the most difficult vault in the women's rulebook and today's landing was the best of the Paris Games, earning a 15.700.

For her second vault, she did a “Cheng,” or a half-turn onto the vaulting table, followed by a 1.5 twist into the air. That scored a 14.900, for a 15.300 average between the two vaults.

She is currently in first place by a wide margin, but Brazil's Rebeca Andrade and U.S. gymnast Jade Carey are still to come. They will be the other frontrunners for the podium.

Soccer: 90 minutes gone and still no goals

It’s the end of normal time in the soccer quarter final between the United States and Japan. With the game still goalless we will play another 30 minutes, and, after that, penalties if there’s still no winner.

It was a frantic end to the 90 minutes, with goal-mouth scrambles at both ends. The USWNT had a penalty shout waved away by the referee, only for Japan to run down the other end and narrowly miss with an ambitious long-range lobbed effort over American ‘keeper Alyssa Naeher.

Team USA hasn't won an individual men's gymnastics medal since 2016

The U.S. men's gymnastics team last took home individual event medals in 2016. If Stephen Nederoscik does today what he came to do on pommel horse, he could end an eight-year drought.

In Rio, Danell Leyva won silver on the pommel horse and the high bar, and Alex Naddour won bronze on the pommel horse.

Aside from Nederoscik, no other men qualified for individual event finals in Paris.

Soccer crowd getting restless

Reporting from Paris

Boos and whistles fill the Parc des Princes as the USWNT pass the ball up and down its own defensive line. You can see why the American players are reluctant to get it forward too quickly; they don't seem to have the quality of final pass when up against Japan's low block.

With just over 75 minutes gone in this women's soccer quarter final, the second half as been much more even than the American-dominated first, with good chances at both ends.

Boxing: Omari Jones punches ticket to welterweight semifinals

Reporting from Villepinte, France

American Omari Jones won his quarterfinal welterweight bout against Rami Mofid Kiwan, disposing of the taller Bulgarian southpaw by unanimous decision.

The Orlando, Florida native won each round on the cards of all five judges. He'll next fight on Tuesday.

Gymnastics: How do you win a vault medal?

To win an individual apparatus medal in vault, gymnasts must perform two vaults that have different entries onto the vaulting table. The two scores are averaged to determine the podium.

Simone Biles is expected to performed her iconic namesake vault, the Yurchenko double pike, or “Biles II.” Her second vault is typically a “Cheng,” which features an additional half-turn onto the table, followed by a 1.5 twist into the air.

Vincent Hancock wins historic fourth gold medal as Team USA also take silver in men's skeet shooting

Team USA's Vincent Hancock has won his fourth Olympic gold medal in the men's skeet shooting, becoming just the sixth Olympian to win four golds in the same individual event.

The gold is Team USA's 10th of these Games. Team USA also took silver with Conner Prince, who is coached and mentored by Olympic veteran Hancock. With Hancock and Prince tied heading into the final four targets, Prince, shooting first, missed one of his four targets. With Hancock landing all four of his shots, he locked up the top spot on the podium.

Skeet sees competitors shoot flying clay targets with shotguns. Hancock also won gold in the men's skeet in Beijing, London and Tokyo and now joins the likes of Michael Phelps and Carl Lewis in becoming a four-time Olympic champion in an individual event.

Katie Ledecky has the opportunity to join Hancock in winning four individual gold medals in the same event tonight in the women's 800m freestyle final.

Gymnastics: New skill watch for Brazil’s Andrade

Like Simone Biles and her eponymous vault, Brazil's Rebeca Andrade’s name could soon be in the rulebook.

Andrade has been teasing a new vault that has never been performed by a female gymnast, a triple-twisting Yurchenko. If she performs it in today's vault final, it will bear her name in the Code of Points and help close her difficulty gap with Biles.

She would become the first woman to ever do the vault successfully in competition, though other gymnasts have attempted it before. It's a risky endeavor for a gymnast like Andrade that has suffered three ACL tears, but today's final will be her last chance.

Tennis: Fritz and Paul win bronze in men's doubles

After Austin Krajicek and Rajeev Ram took silver in men's doubles, Team USA secured a double podium finish as Taylor Fritz and Tommy Paul defeated Czech team Tomas Machac and Adam Pavlasek in straight sets.

The U.S. pairs had powerful runs, beating out Spanish superstars Rafael Nadal and Carlos Alcaraz.

Gymnastics: Carlos Yulo takes floor gold, becoming first man to win Olympic gold for the Philippines

No man from the Philippines had never won an Olympic gold medal in any sport. Carlos Yulo, 24, outscored Israel's Artem Dolgopyat and Great Britain's Jake Jarman to win their first in the floor exercise apparatus final.

Because the Philippines did not qualify a team to the Olympics, Yulo is competing in Paris as an individual. Three former U.S. gymnasts switched national federations to represent the Philippines on the women's side, but were also competing as individuals and could not contend for a team medal.

Soccer: Big chance for Japan

The second half is underway in this quarter final and the first big chance goes to Japan, who cut the ball back across the penalty box only for USWNT defender Crystal Dunn to clear behind for a corner.

More gold for Simone?

Reporting from Paris

After claiming gold in the team and individual all-around competitions earlier this week, Simone Biles is eyeing the top spot on the podium in the vault competition today.

If she wins, she would become just the fourth U.S. woman to win at least seven gold medals and would join Czechoslovakia’s Vera Caslavska as the only women ever to win two vault gold medals. Caslavska did it in 1964 and 1968.

Biles will face a familiar foe today in Brazil's Rebeca Andrade, who took gold in the vault at Tokyo and is the reigning world champion. Andrade took silver on Thursday in the individual all-around.

A half of possession for USWNT, but no goals

Reporting from Paris

Half time in the women's soccer quarter final between USWNT and Japan, and it's still goalless at 0-0.

The Americans have had 78% of possession, but without anything to show for it beyond a few semi-decent shots. Meanwhile, Japan's two promising attempts on goal will remind U.S. coach Emma Hayes that this contest is still very much in the balance.

Caeleb Dressel on his inner critic: 'Nothing is ever good enough'

After winning five gold medals at Tokyo, Caeleb Dressel opened up about his struggles with being overly self-critical and how he has learned to develop a healthier relationship with the water.

So far at the Paris Games, Dressel helped win gold for Team USA in the 4x100m freestyle relay, but could not defend his gold in the 50m free and 100m butterfly. He will swim tomorrow to defend Team USA's gold in the men's 4x00m medley relay final.

Track: Kenny Bednarek posts top time in his 100m heat

U.S. athlete Kenny Bednarek posted the top time of 9.96 in his 100m heat, immediately qualifying for the 100m semifinal. His run was relatively effortless, not needing to go that deep to outrun the other racers.

Behind Bednarek were Cameroon's Emmanuel Eseme and Canada's Andre De Grasse, who also qualified for the semifinal having posted the other two fastest times.

Shots at either end in soccer

Reporting from Paris

After really struggling for possession in this first half, Japan has just had two very promising shots in just as many minutes.

First Mina Tanaka danced across the penalty box, only to prod a relatively tame shot at American goalkeeper Alyssa Naeher. Then Miyabi Moriya latched onto to a chaotically bouncing ball in the penalty area, but her shot was high and wild.

Before that, USWNT had possibly its best chance of this quarter final, too, with Sophia Smith running onto a long ball after a flicked header from Lindsey Horan, but slicing her effort wide.

Almost 40 minutes gone here.

Golf: Tommy Fleetwood takes the lead with Xander Schauffele off the pace in third round

The overnight leaders are through 11 holes in the third round of the men's golf, and it is currently Team GB's Tommy Fleetwood that is at the top of the leaderboard on 13-under-par.

Fleetwood, who won the 2017 French Open at Le Golf National, was tied for the lead coming into the day with Team USA's Xander Schauffele and Hideki Matsuyama of Japan. Fleetwood though has broken the tie, he is two-under for the round so far with Schauffele even-par. Matsuyama is one-over for the day.

Denmark's Nikolai Hojgaard has been the flier of the day, moving himself into medal contention with a brilliant round of nine-under-par. He currently sits on 11-under - the same score as Schauffele.

Spain's Jon Rahm is also having a good day on the course. He is three-under for the day through 11 holes and currently sits one shot behind Fleetwood. Rory McIlroy has also moved into medal contention - he is five-under for the day and sits on 10-under overall through 15 holes in this third round.

A track designed to break records

Yesterday's brakeneck 10,000m race stunned the Stade de France as the top 13 finishers all beat the previous Olympic record, with Uganda’s Joshua Cheptegei coming out on top.

It was a stunning race full of athletes at the top of their game, but this is also a track designed to break records.

Italian company Mondo has provided the track at every Summer Games since 1976, and this time they’ve gone back to the drawing board with records in mind, with a track engineered to produce fast times.

It took 10 weeks to install in the Stade de France, but Mondo says the track is its fastest yet, and 2% faster than Tokyo’s.

The women’s 200-meter world record, which has stood since 1988, could be under threat. Jamaica’s Shericka Jackson set the second fastest time ever in 2023, and may fancy her chances on Paris' purple track.

Vincent Hancock aiming to make history in skeet shooting final

Team USA's Vincent Hancock is aiming to make Olympic history in the men's skeet shooting final shortly — he is aiming to become just the sixth Olympian to win four gold medals in the same individual event.

Hancock, a gold medalist in the skeet in Beijing, London and Tokyo, is aiming to join Al Oerter, Paul Elvstrom, Carl Lewis, Michael Phelps and Mijain Lopez in achieving that incredible feat. Katie Ledecky also has the chance to win a fourth Olympic gold medal tonight in the 800-meter freestyle.

Fellow American Conner Prince has also qualified for the skeet final. The final gets underway imminently.

Why is Hungary so good at water polo?

The men's and women's water polo starts today in Paris, with Hungary's legendary men's team among the favorites to take home a gold.

In fact, the Hungarian men's team are gunning for their tenth Olympic gold medal in the event. Already on nine, they have won more than twice as many as the next most successful country.

The landlocked nation owes its peculiar dominance in the pool to its 1,300 thermal springs. The warm water allows Hungarians to practice for longer periods during the year, while they have fostered an aquatic culture in the eastern European nation.

They were also early innovators in the sport, which helped them toward a 110-match winning streak between 1928 and 1939, a run that included gold at the 1932 Los Angeles Olympics.

But since their last gold in 2008, they've suffered a relative drought. After failing to finish on the podium in either 2012 and 2016, the men only managed Bronze in Tokyo.

Will Paris see a return to form for the legendary side?

American soccer dominance, but not much to show for it

Reporting from Paris

The first 15 minutes are up in the women's soccer quarter final between USWNT and Japan. And although the Americans have been utterly dominant — enjoying 89% of possession so far — they've only had one shot on target.

Japan hasn't been able to get near the neat triangles conducted by Rose Lavelle and Lindsey Horan in the midfield. But when it comes to the final third, the U.S. just hasn't had the quality needed to break the Japanese defensive lines.

Simone Biles and Jade Carey are up on the vault final

Simone Biles and Jade Carey are among the top eight vaulters in the world. Today, they will each prove if they are top three material.

Biles is coming out of qualifiers with a massive 15.300 on the event, which is often considered her best. She even has two skills on the vault named after her.

Carey was in third after qualifiers, posting a 14.433 despite struggling with illness that day. She placed eighth in the vault final in Tokyo.

Huge vaults from Biles and Carey on Tuesday helped Team USA bring home a gold medal in the team final.

Their biggest competition today will come from Brazilian powerhouse Rebeca Andrade. She sits in second place after qualifiers with a 14.683.

Each of the eight vaulters will perform two vaults from two different families. Their scores will be averaged to produce a final result.

Will Simone Biles perform the Biles I and II?

Simone Biles is expected to compete in the vault later today, where she may also perform at least one of the moves named after her in the sport.

At the 2018 world championships, Biles debuted the Biles vault I, a roundoff, back handspring with half turn entry, front stretched somersault with two twists.

Six years later, she is still the only woman who has performed Biles I, but it is only the second-most difficult in vault in women’s artistic gymnastics, after the Biles II.

The Biles II, a round-off back handspring with two backward flips in pike position, is the most dazzling and daring move in the sport. Biles drew a standing ovation after she performed the move at the U.S. Olympic trials in July, and may try it again during today’s event.

Biles also has moves named after her in the floor exercise and balance beam events.

Soccer: American women will hope the goals keep coming

Reporting from Paris

On a hot scoring spree, the United States Women’s National Team will face Japan later today in the women’s soccer quarter final.

The USWNT bagged a record nine goals while winning all three of its matches to top group B. Japan was runner up in Group C.

The game kicks off at 3 p.m. local time (9 a.m. ET).

If the U.S. triumphs, it will play the winner of the quarter final between Canada and Germany, which is being played at 1 p.m. ET.

The ancient origins of pommel horse and triple jump

The men’s pommel horse event has attracted all sorts of attention in Paris thanks to Team USA’s Stephen Nedoroscik, who helped seal the bronze medal in the team all-around on Thursday.

The peculiar apparatus has since become a talking point, but its origins date way back to the ancient Olympics and the stables of Rome.

The pommel horse descends from a wooden horse used by the Romans to teach mounting and dismounting. Pommel horse featured in the ancient Olympics and was among the events at the first modern Olympics in 1896.

The women’s triple jump final, which takes place this evening, is also thought to be related to the eternal children’s game of hopscotch. However, there is no evidence that it was used in the ancient Olympics.

Silver for Team USA in men's tennis doubles

Team USA has taken home silver in the men's tennis doubles after coming up short in an enthralling contest against Australia.

The American pair, Austin Krajicek and Rajeev Ram, played three tiebreaks in a closely fought contest but couldn't quite get it over the line against Matthew Ebden and John Peers, who won gold.Krajicek and Ram started well, taking the first set and breaking their opponents' serve in the second. However, the Australians broke back and had the momentum thereafter, winning the deciding tiebreak 10-8.

Team USA facing first Olympics without a male individual swimming gold since 1900

So far it has been an Olympics to forget for the American men in the pool — they have zero individual swimming gold medals so far and there is only one more chance to end that drought.

That will come down to Bobby Finke tomorrow night.

Finke qualified with the sixth fastest time this morning in the 1500-meter freestyle final. He is the defending Olympic champion and is set to face a stern test this time from reigning world champion Daniel Wiffen of Ireland. Wiffen has already claimed gold in the 800-meter freestyle in these Games.

If Finke doesn't claim gold tomorrow, it will be the first Olympics in which American male swimmers have failed to claim an individual gold medal since the 1900 Games.

That means it’s one set each, which will now force a special 10-point tiebreaker instead of the third set. The winner of that gets the match — and gold.

IOC President says online abuse 'unacceptable' amid women's boxing dispute

International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach has responded to questions surrounding the gender dispute over Taiwanese boxer Lin Yu-ting and Imane Khelif of Algeria.

Both athletes failed to meet gender eligibility tests at the Women’s World Boxing Championships in New Delhi last year, but they were cleared to compete in Paris by the IOC, and have also always competed in women's divisions.

"We have two boxers who were born as women, who have been raised as women, who have a passport as a woman, and who have competed for many years as women," said Bach.

"There was never any doubt about them being women."

Khelif's win over Italy's Angela Carini Thursday provoked massive criticism online, including from prominent figures such as Elon Musk and J.K. Rowling.

"What we see now is that some want to own the definition of who is a woman," added Bach.

"All this hate speech, aggression and abuse...is totally unacceptable."

Models of boats donated for answered prayers hang in Marseille basilica as sailing events begin

and

The first sailing medals are up for grabs today as the women’s and men’s windsurfing events take place in Marseille.

The city is inextricably linked to its seafaring city, a reverence shown by the votive offerings that sit in its basilica of Notre Dame de la Garde.

Little model boats hang from its ceiling and maritime paintings adorn its walls. These are votive offerings, some more than 200 year old that residents of this Mediterranean port city continue to bring in gratitude to the Virgin Mary for everything from avoiding shipwrecks to successful rescues of migrants trying to make it to Europe on unseaworthy boats.

About once a month someone brings a new one — sometimes with an explanation, sometimes anonymously, most handmade.

A fresh set of Olympic medalists may have offerings of their own by the end of the day.

Track: Noah Lyles sends warning shot to his rivals

Fresh from a second-place finish in his 100-meter heat, Team USA's Noah Lyles has warned his rivals he is even more pumped up now that his quest for Olympic gold is underway.

Lyles progressed to the semifinals in a time of 10.04s after making up for a sluggish start off the starting blocks. It was more than enough to see him safely through to tomorrow night's semifinals, and Lyles says the complacency that affected him in the heats will not be on display tomorrow night.

"I didn't put enough emphasis on the acceleration, this time it just kind of got away from me," Lyles reflected after his heat. "I'm not going to lie, I downplayed my competitors. But don't worry, that won't happen again."

“To be honest, I think I’m more excited now that I didn’t win that heat. I’m pretty scared for everyone else right now.”

When Lyles made his Olympic debut in Tokyo in 2021, he admitted that the lack of crowds at the Games really got to him, describing his bronze medal win as "boring." Around those Games, he also opened up about his struggles with his mental health, particularly perpetuated by the ongoing Covid pandemic and the pressures of life as a black American following the murder of George Floyd.

Since then, Lyles has become a global star, winning both the 100-meter and 200-meter titles at last year's World Championships in Budapest - the first athlete to sweep those titles since Usain Bolt. Last month, "Sprint," a behind-the-scenes Netflix documentary focusing on the fastest humans on the planet, premiered with Lyles as one of its main stars.

"It's a lot more exciting, it's way different," Lyles said about competing in front of the packed-out Stade de France. "'Sprint' came out. I now walk around and everyone knows who I am. It's a completely different environment so I'm just getting acclimated to that. I'm going in step-by-step saying hey, let's just have some fun."

Team USA clinches hard-fought opening set in men's tennis doubles

Both teams broke each other's serve during the start of the set, but every time the United States looked like pulling away, the Australians somehow clawed it back. The U.S. finally won the tiebreak 8-6 on points.

Badminton spectator dragged from arena for holding up Taiwan banner

Taiwan’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs has condemned the removal of a spectator from the badminton venue at the Paris Olympics for holding up a green banner reading “Taiwan go for it” during competition on Friday.

Taiwan competes at the Olympics as Chinese Taipei to avoid objections from China, which claims the democratically governed island as its own territory. Taiwan’s government rejects Chinese sovereignty claims.

Two Reuters journalists saw the spectator being bodily removed up a staircase, shouting, while Taiwanese shuttler Chou Tien Chen was playing.

“This violent act is not only ill educated but also seriously violates the spirit of civilization represented by the Olympic Games,” Taiwan’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement on Saturday. “It is even more contrary to the rule of law and infringes on freedom of expression.”

Early crowd banter in the men's doubles tennis final

Reporting from Paris

Play is under way here at Roland-Garros where Team USA’s Austin Krajicek and Rajeev Ram are playing Australia’s Matthew Ebden and John Peers for a gold medal in the men’s tennis doubles.

In the first game someone got a “USA! USA! USA!” chant going. And now an Australian fan has piped up with “Aussie! Aussie Aussie!” to which someone on the other side of the ground responded “oi! oi! oi!”

Another supporter has just yelled over the pre-serve silence, “Do you want to marry me?” Perhaps that was a reference to the iconic moment at Wimbledon in 1996, when Germany's Steffi Graf was asked by a supporter, “Steffi, will you marry me?” She famously responded, “How much money do you have?”

Adding to the good vibes, the in-house brass band has struck up a rendition of the Addams Family theme tune.

Noah Lyles second in heat, progresses to tomorrow's semifinals

Team USA's Noah Lyles is safely through to tomorrow's 100-meter semifinals after finishing second in his heat to get his bid to win four gold medals underway.

A little slow off the blocks, Lyles, the reigning 100-meter and 200-meter world champion, posted a time of 10.04 seconds. Of course, we won't see the really fast times until tomorrow with the medal favorites mostly conserving their energy in the heats.

Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, widely seen as Lyles' main rival for gold, strolled over the line in 10.00 seconds to win his heat, having eased off considerably after the first 50m.

Team Great Britain Azu disqualified from 100m after false start

Heartbreak for Team GB athlete Jeremiah Azu, who was disqualified from the 100-meter after a false start ahead of his heat.

The Brit reacted to the gun in 0.073 seconds, breaking the accepted reaction time of 0.10 seconds. Azu pleaded his case but was escorted from the track, his Olympic dream over for another four years.

Azu is the only Welshman in history to have run 100 meters in less than 10 seconds.

The race was eventually won by Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.

Tennis: Team USA hoping for double podium in men's doubles

Team USA are guaranteed a medal in the men's doubles with Austin Krajicek and Rajeev Ram due to take to the courts of Roland-Garros shortly for the gold medal match.

Ram, who won silver with Venus Williams in the mixed doubles in 2016, and Krajicek have won all their matches en route to the final in straight sets, including a 6-2, 6-4 quarterfinal win against Rafael Nadal and Carlos Alcaraz to end the 'Nadalcaraz' dream. They now face Australia's duo Matthew Ebden and John Peers for gold starting at 6:00 a.m. ET.

At 40 years old, Ram will become the oldest player to win an Olympic medal in tennis since 1920.

The U.S. could double up in this event — Taylor Fritz and Tommy Paul are in the bronze medal match. They face Czech pair Tomas Machac and Adam Pavlasek later today for the final spot on the podium.

It is Team USA's second medal in the rowing regatta after the men's four took gold on Thursday. The U.S. failed to earn a single medal in rowing in Tokyo.

Great Britain charged ahead in the final 500m to take gold ahead of the Netherlands.

In the women's event earlier this morning, the Team USA crew faded towards the end, eventually finishing 5th.

Father of Algerian boxer caught in Olympics gender dispute calls it ‘immoral’ and ‘unfair’

and

Amar Khelif, father of Algerian boxer Imane Khelif who remains embroiled in a dispute over her gender, has slammed the debate surrounding his daughter and paid tribute to his "honourable" daughter.

Imane Khelif’s win over Italy’s Angela Carini on Thursday sparked global outrage after reports resurfaced that she failed to meet gender eligibility tests at the Women’s World Boxing Championships in New Delhi last year.

But there is there is no indication that Khelif identifies as transgender or intersex, and she has always competed in women’s events, including at the Tokyo Olympics.

“Having such a daughter is honorable because she is a champion,” he told Reuters. “The attacks against her are immoral, it is not fair, Imane is a little girl that has loved sport since she was 6 years old.”

“These critics aim to destabilize her to fail in the wrestling ring but she is a champion and she will remain a champion and I hope she will win the gold medal and make us happy, she is our role model not only here at the club but the role model for Algerian boxing.”

The 'fastest man in the world?' The pressure is on Noah Lyles to prove it

“What’s up, Team USA? This is Noah Lyles, fastest man in the world.”

That is the bold claim Noah Lyles made in a video posted to Team USA's X account during the opening ceremony, and it's a statement that has many athletics fans around the world riled up and waiting to see if he can back it up.

The 27-year-old has never been short of confidence; after all, he is the reigning 100m and 200m world champion, titles that the Gainsville native says give him the right to the fastest man in the world title.

Jamaica's Kishane Thompson may have something to say about that. Both Thompson and Lyles have run personal bests this year in the 100m, but Thompson's was faster - 9.77 against Lyles' 9.81. Kenya’s Ferdinand Omanyala has also gone quicker than Lyles in 2024.

Even so, Lyles is adamant he is the fastest man in the world, and now the time has come for him to prove it. "It’s me," Lyles said while laughing, doubling down on his fastest-man claim during a Team USA press conference this week. “It’s always going to be me.”

Lyles goes in the first heats of the 100m this morning at 5:55 a.m. ET ahead of tomorrow's final.

‘It’s just exciting’: Olympic superfan on his 13th Olympics

Ron Isbell has attended 13 Olympic Games. He arrived in Paris with tickets to 40 different events.

Isbell, a distance runner in high school and college, got started on his own Olympic journey after he won a trip to the 1988 Calgary Winter Olympics.

"That got me interested in the Winter Games and I saw how much fun it was to go there, so just started going," he said. "Eventually I thought I'll just keep going to all of them as long as I can."

Isbell has brought about 800 Olympic pins with him to trade — part of his collection of more than 1,000.

"It's just a lot of fun to meet other people from other countries and they may not even speak your language but you're able to make a pin trade with them," he said.

Why do so many countries have red, white and blue flags?

At the Olympic Games, the vibrant display of national flags is always a highlight.

With the flags regularly appearing on scoreboards and celebrating throughout the events, it’s easy to spot their similarities, especially with colors like red, white, blue and yellow.

Ted Kaye, Secretary of the North American Vexillological Association (NAVA), an organization that studies flag designs, discusses why certain colors are so common in flags and how they show historical influences and cultural meanings.
